name: SingleCompile
summary: Make it more convenient to compile or run a single source file.
description:
This plugin aims at making it more convenient to compile or run a single source file without leaving vim.

Consider this situation: you have just written a small c source file for a tiny test, but if you want to compile it within vim, you have to write a Makefile, or use the command "!gcc" without quickfix feature(That means, you can not locate your error quickly)? This plugin will help you out.

add these key-mappings to your vimrc:

 nmap <F9> :SingleCompile<cr>
 nmap <C-F9> :SingleCompileRun<cr>

If your file type is supported, then press F9 to compile your source file, and press Ctrl-F9 to compile and run your source file. Here is a list of supported language:

version 0.1 and above: C, C++, Java, sh(UNIX shell), dos batch
version 0.2 and above: html, xhtml, vb script
version 0.4 and above: LaTeX
version 0.8 and above: python, Makefile
version 1.0 and above: cmake

NOTE: built-in html and xhtml built-in support requires for firefox on UNIX/Linux and IE on Windows. Of course you can define your prefered browser if you don't have firefox or IE. LaTeX built-in support is only for tex-live.

You can add your language if your language is not in the list. See details in the help file SingleCompile.txt

Interpreting language such as vb script can also be supported by this plugin, see details in the help file SingleCompile.txt.

note: this plugin cannot deal with a project with more than one source file.

if you have any question, send an email to xuhdev AT gmail DOT com.

Here is a list of plugins which SingleCompile is supporting:
Marc Weber's vim-addon-actions: http://github.com/MarcWeber/vim-addon-actions


check the latest code at: http://code.google.com/p/single-compile/source/checkout
install_details:
Download the SingleCompile.zip file and extract it to your vim runtime
directory(~/.vim on linux and $VIM_INSTALLATION_FOLDER\vimfiles on windows).

add "filetype on" to your vimrc if you haven't.

add python and Makefile built-in support.

fix a bug: when dealing with interpreting languages and quickfix is enabled for this plugin, nothing will be shown on the screen.
set g:SingleCompile_usedialog to 0 as default from now on.
add a quickfix check.
